When will Lebanon's parliament give a vote of confidence to a new government?
Hattip to @cm2310 for providing a window and framework to better understand this situation.

The time scope of the base rate for this question is extremely low.  Lebanon has a history of taking a very long time to form a government and get a vote of confidence.  Due to Lebanon’s sectarian power-sharing agreement, it is difficult under the best of circumstances to form a government within its sectarian political system.  According to the Economist (https://www.economist.com/the-economist-explains/2018/12/21/why-lebanon-struggles-to-form-governments), it took two and a half years for Lebanon to elect its previous president, “nine years to hold parliamentary elections, and 12 years to pass a budget…Lebanon has spent nearly two and a half of the past 13 years without a government.”  Political talks in Lebanon have a long history of dragging on for months with little resolution.    While the economic situation in Lebanon appears dire, the protestors have not been supportive of the new government in the media.  From a regional perspective, Lebanon will have a difficult time getting badly needed financial aid and support from Gulf countries due to the government being shaped by Hezbollah.  That being said, the new government may have the needed votes in Parliament to get a vote of confidence (https://www.lorientlejour.com/article/1203655/cap-sur-le-vote-de-confiance.html).   My dilemma with this forecast is given the severity of the economic situation and the growing protests, it would seem logical that Parliament would want to pass a confidence vote asap on a new government, but the historic base rate and precedent indicates that this situation will not end quickly.  Also, Lebanon has a long history of political strife, and the traditional power brokers are not involved with the current government.  There are ample opportunities for sectarian spoilers, which further decreases the chances of a confidence vote happening quickly.  The new government should be presenting its plan to Parliament soon.  Once that occurs, we should see some indicators based on Parliament’s reaction and the reaction of the protestors to determine whether the vote of confidence will occur and whether the government has the needed support.  Since Parliament will be voting sooner than later, the forecast between now and 29 Feb is higher than the following months.  If the confidence vote fails, it most likely will take another few months to form a new government.
This newspaper tell us that a majority could be find ( more than 65) https://www.lorientlejour.com/article/1203655/cap-sur-le-vote-de-confiance.html
Though government is formed, Parliament has not yet voted.  Given pending financial crisis, I think Parliament will act sooner rather than later.

Now that a new government has been formed (see link), the next question is when will parliament vote on it. While that isn't clear yet, I think the violence in the streets makes delay likely.  I think either parliament is able to approve the government in the next few weeks (by the end of February) or the chaos right now will wreck the whole attempt. In that case, the elites will have to try something else and that will take a while to figure out.  https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/01/lebanon-announces-formation-government-200121200947113.html

Hattip @MJF20 and @OConnorNWC for their insights convincing me to weigh the out months more heavily.

Based on a number of articles (including those cited for this question), Lebanon takes a lot of time to form a government and this newly elected Prime Minister seems to be having the usual challenges in getting the support he needs. Therefore, it is more likely to happen later in the year than earlier.

Lebanon has recently gone years without a government and despite the current turmoil, deep divisions persist.
https://www.economist.com/the-economist-explains/2018/12/21/why-lebanon-struggles-to-form-governments

Over the last decade, governments haven taken from five to over ten months to form, with the most recent government taking eight months, reportedly with strong external intervention/support from France. The Hariri government resigned at the end of Oct 2019, placing the first window of success into March/April. While the new PM has vowed to speedily form a government, ongoing geopolitical tensions, lack of support from the movement that brought down the Hariri government (and their desire for technocrats in key ministerial posts), and lack of support from his own confessional sect, do not point to a speedy process. Nor does the PM’s likely inability to secure assurances of western financial support during a period of economic duress, given that Hezbollah is his main source of support. Started with a set of percentages that reflected the average time to form a government in the last decade, and made adjustments based on the complicating factors raised above.

When will Lebanon's parliament give a vote of confidence to a new government?
Hattip @Wildwood2000 for the research shared.

End of the party: why Lebanon’s debt crisis has left it vulnerable
*
Once known for its resilience, the country’s fragile financial system has triggered angry protests
*
Cornish (2019) December 31, stated that:
*
But by 2016, argues former IMF official and economist Toufic Gaspard, who anticipated the crisis in a 2017 paper, the central bank “became a Ponzi scheme. It was borrowing from banks to pay them their interest” (Para 34) Mr Salame rejects this accusation. The financial engineering was to buy time, he said, for politicians to reform the bloated government and curb spending. But the stability it bought “is not a pretext not to do reforms”, he insists. He warned that Banque du Liban should not be used for politics: “The central bank is not an instrument to be used in order to force certain changes” . The state depends on the central bank to meet its dollar debt servicing obligations, which will cost around $4bn next year. But rating agencies say that on a net basis, the bank’s foreign currency holdings are negative. Its forex reserves will be $28bn by the end of the year, yet Fitch estimates that the central bank’s dollar liabilities to Lebanese banks stand at $67bn. Moody’s says requests to the IMF are “credit positive”, and a new government — under Mr Diab — may start talks about a new loan programme, which could provide some much-needed financial stability. But first the fractious political factions — including Hizbollah — have to form a government. They will also need to win back the support of a sceptical public. “The whole political system was bought with this Ponzi scheme,” says Ms Rizk (Para 34-38).  *
Reference
*
Cornish, C. (2019). End of the party: why Lebanon’s debt crisis has left it vulnerable. Financial Times. World. December 31, 2019. Retrieved from
https://www.ft.com/content/078b2e4a-266a-11ea-9305-4234e74b0ef3
* Lebanon is prepared to give Hassan Diab a chance. It has little choice The prime minister's lack of communal backing will plague him in the months ahead, particularly when the government has to take tough economic measures. Young (2019) Dec 26, states that: Two things can be said about the efforts of Hezbollah and its allies in the Amal Movement and the Free Patriotic Movement (FPM) to push through a Lebanese government that would protect their interests, under the premiership of Hassan Diab (Para 1). First, they apparently succeeded in imposing Mr Diab on a large part of the protest movement that had been in the streets since October 17. And second, while the protesters may have taken a wait-and-see approach, Mr Diab does not enjoy support among his Sunni community. Having been named by several of the political parties associated with Lebanon’s economic mismanagement, he will struggle to implement the structural reforms needed for the country to emerge from its financial crisis. While Mr Diab began forming his government last Saturday, the signs are that he would like to lead a government mainly of experts, even if named by the political parties. While this will not satisfy the demand of the protest movement for a government of independent technocrats, for now it could buy the parties in power time to breathe. With the economic situation deteriorating, people are inclined to give Mr Diab a chance. The Lebanese have few alternatives. The political crisis that started last October had dragged on for more than two months when Mr Diab was named. In the interim, the economy had come to a standstill as banks, in order to survive, imposed unofficial capital controls while severely reducing the amount of money people could withdraw from their accounts. The outcome was that many businesses, unable to operate effectively, laid off workers, provoking a rise in unemployment at the worst conceivable time (Para 1-4).
*
Reference
*
Young, M. (2019). Lebanon is prepared to give Hassan Diab a chance. It has little choice. The National. Opinion. Comment. Dec 26, 2019. Retrieved from
https://www.thenational.ae/opinion/comment/lebanon-is-prepared-to-give-hassan-diab-a-chance-it-has-little-choice-1.956211
Crowd forecast, need to do more research.
The new minister is a Hezbollah man, but protesters reacted strongly and immediately so not pulling the trigger on this first try - not yet.

I started off favouring something in distant future (beyond July 2020) and still feel that way but things could move quicker than I expect given rising dissatisfaction with status quo. Worth keeping an eye on this. From Economist:
“A second successive night of violent clashes between anti-government protesters and Lebanese security forces left dozens of people wounded. Lebanon is currently facing its worst economic downturn in years and protesters accuse the country’s elite of mismanagement and corruption. Following the violence, the president, Michel Aoun, announced that formal consultations to select the next prime minister would be delayed until Thursday.”

The situation in Lebanon is much more complicated than it seems at first. The vote in 2019 was several years behind schedule. A lot of people put faith in the new government that they elected in early 2019 but it became obvious that nothing had changed after Saad Hariri's victory in the election.  Lebanon has struggled to recover after its civil war that lasted 25 years (1975-1990) and has left the country in a critical state. Lebanon has one of the highest per capita debts. This has led to a large majority of people who can not afford to live in the country. This is just one of the major problems that thousands of people have been protesting to correct.  The political structure in Lebanon is probably one of the largest reasons for its political unrest. To create peace after the Civil war they made the government non-secular and required specific positions to be held by people of a certain religion. This bolstered the divide in the country and prevented any social changes from actually happening.  All these reasons and more suggest that this will not be decided in a reasonable time frame. The people have become outraged and taken to the streets and are demanding change and will continue to protest till actual change is made. Whether or not this will happen the government will take its time before coming up with a new solution.

Some background info from The Economist. All signs point to nothing quick and possibly something messy in the interim:
“Lebanon repaid a $1.5bn Eurobond that matures today. For most countries that would be no big deal. But Lebanon borrows more than most. Its debt burden is expected to reach 155% of GDP by the end of the year. Its bonds are already rated as junk. Investors are increasingly worried that the government, which spends more than it brings in, will default. A dollar shortage adds to the sense of crisis. Economists say a plan is needed to restructure the debt and introduce structural reforms. Alas, Lebanon lacks the leadership needed to do that. Big anti-government protests forced the prime minister, Saad Hariri, to resign last month. (He has remained in a caretaker role, but ruled out a return.) The demonstrators now hope to bring down the sectarian political system, which breeds corruption. Lately they have clashed with supporters of groups, such as Hizbullah, that benefit from the status quo. Both politically and financially Lebanon is a mess.”

At the moment parliament isn't even meeting, much less figuring out a way forward. Given the gulf between protesters and traditional elites, I doubt the situation is going to calm down enough for anyone to form a government for months.
Lebanon is not a fast-moving country

This news article provides great background into what has happened and what will happen going forward. Since the resignation was accepted, a new government needs to be formed. Hence the "vote of confidence." The article also discusses the process of forming a new Lebanese government. They say "typically takes several months. It took Lebanon’s factions 2 ½ years to agree on the current president, and it took nine months to form Hariri’s now-embattled government."  The steps to forming a new government include 
1) The Council is formed by a Decree of the President of the Republic, which is countersigned by the Prime Minister. 
2) Within 30 days, the House of Deputies must approve the Government through a vote of confidence, which requires a simple majority. [2]  This suggests to me that this requires a new Prime Minster to be picked, which definitely will take time.  Let me know if I've gotten anything drastically wrong. I'm going to think more about the process of forming a government and try to establish a good base rate for how long these have taken in Lebanon's history.  [1] https://apnews.com/4021c1400bc14f2ebb38a2fdf2dc7a41
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_Lebanon

Factors going against vote of confidence to a new government in the immediate future (among others):
1. Demands from protesters - they have no faith in the existing political elite and the old guard
2. Past track record of government formation in Lebanon - long delays, political wheeler dealing, sectarian politics
3. Meddling by Iran to continue to destabilize the country
4. A candidate from the old guard is unlikely to be acceptable to protesters Factors that would aid in vote of confidence and government formation (among many others):
1. Economic crisis - intervention of IMF or donor countries such a France to quickly address the crisis
2. A prime ministerial candidate from the traditional elite who is acceptable to all stake holders (including protesters)
3. Fizzling out of the protests (since it is decentralized)
4. Quelling of protests by military/ police/ Hizbullah
